[](https://docs.rs/sqlx/latest/sqlx/all.html "show sidebar")
# Crate sqlxCopy item path
[Settings](https://docs.rs/sqlx/latest/settings.html)
[Help](https://docs.rs/sqlx/latest/help.html)
Summary[Source](https://docs.rs/sqlx/latest/src/sqlx/lib.rs.html#1-174)
Expand description
The async SQL toolkit for Rust, built with ❤️ by [the LaunchBadge team](https://www.launchbadge.com).
See our [README](https://www.github.com/launchbadge/sqlx/tree/main/README.md) to get started or [browse our example projects](https://www.github.com/launchbadge/sqlx/tree/main/examples). Have a question? [Check our FAQ](https://www.github.com/launchbadge/sqlx/tree/main/FAQ.md) or [open a discussion](https://github.com/launchbadge/sqlx/discussions/new?category=q-a).
#### [§](https://docs.rs/sqlx/latest/sqlx/#runtime-support)Runtime Support
SQLx supports both the [Tokio](https://www.tokio.rs) and [async-std](https://www.async.rs) runtimes.
You choose which runtime SQLx uses by default by enabling one of the following features:
  * `runtime-async-std`
  * `runtime-tokio`


The `runtime-actix` feature also exists but is an alias of `runtime-tokio`.
If more than one runtime feature is enabled, the Tokio runtime is used if a Tokio context exists on the current thread, i.e. [`tokio::runtime::Handle::try_current()`](https://docs.rs/tokio/latest/tokio/runtime/struct.Handle.html#method.try_current) returns `Ok`; `async-std` is used otherwise.
Note that while SQLx no longer produces a compile error if zero or multiple runtime features are enabled, which is useful for libraries building on top of it, **the use of nearly any async function in the API will panic without at least one runtime feature enabled**.
The chief exception is the SQLite driver, which is runtime-agnostic, including its integration with the query macros. However, [`SqlitePool`](https://docs.rs/sqlx/latest/sqlx/type.SqlitePool.html "type sqlx::SqlitePool") _does_ require runtime support for timeouts and spawning internal management tasks.
#### [§](https://docs.rs/sqlx/latest/sqlx/#tls-support)TLS Support
For securely communicating with SQL servers over an untrusted network connection such as the internet, you can enable Transport Layer Security (TLS) by enabling one of the following features:
  * `tls-native-tls`: Enables the [`native-tls`](https://docs.rs/native-tls/latest/native_tls/) backend which uses the OS-native TLS capabilities: 
    * SecureTransport on macOS.
    * SChannel on Windows.
    * OpenSSL on all other platforms.
  * `tls-rustls`: Enables the [rustls](https://docs.rs/rustls/latest/rustls/) backend, a cross-platform TLS library. 
    * Only supports TLS revisions 1.2 and 1.3.
    * If you get `HandshakeFailure` errors when using this feature, it likely means your database server does not support these newer revisions. This might be resolved by enabling or switching to the `tls-native-tls` feature.
    * rustls supports several providers of cryptographic primitives. The default (enabled when you use the `tls-rustls` feature or `tls-rustls-ring`) is the `ring` provider, which has fewer build-time dependencies but also has fewer features. Alternatively, you can use `tls-rustls-aws-lc-rs` to use the `aws-lc-rs` provider, which enables additional cipher suite support at the cost of more onerous build requirements (depending on platform support).


If more than one TLS feature is enabled, the `tls-native-tls` feature takes precedent so that it is only necessary to enable it to see if it resolves the `HandshakeFailure` error without disabling `tls-rustls`.
Consult the user manual for your database to find the TLS versions it supports.
If your connection configuration requires a TLS upgrade but TLS support was not enabled, the connection attempt will return an error.
The legacy runtime+TLS combination feature flags are still supported, but for forward-compatibility, use of the separate runtime and TLS feature flags is recommended.
## Modules[§](https://docs.rs/sqlx/latest/sqlx/#modules)

[any](https://docs.rs/sqlx/latest/sqlx/any/index.html "mod sqlx::any")
    **SEE DOCUMENTATION BEFORE USE**. Runtime-generic database driver.

[database](https://docs.rs/sqlx/latest/sqlx/database/index.html "mod sqlx::database")
    Traits to represent a database driver.

[decode](https://docs.rs/sqlx/latest/sqlx/decode/index.html "mod sqlx::decode")
    Provides [`Decode`](https://docs.rs/sqlx/latest/sqlx/trait.Decode.html "trait sqlx::Decode") for decoding values from the database.

[encode](https://docs.rs/sqlx/latest/sqlx/encode/index.html "mod sqlx::encode")
    Provides [`Encode`](https://docs.rs/sqlx/latest/sqlx/trait.Encode.html "trait sqlx::Encode") for encoding values for the database.

[error](https://docs.rs/sqlx/latest/sqlx/error/index.html "mod sqlx::error")
    Types for working with errors produced by SQLx.

[migrate](https://docs.rs/sqlx/latest/sqlx/migrate/index.html "mod sqlx::migrate")


[mysql](https://docs.rs/sqlx/latest/sqlx/mysql/index.html "mod sqlx::mysql")`mysql`
    **MySQL** database driver.

[pool](https://docs.rs/sqlx/latest/sqlx/pool/index.html "mod sqlx::pool")
    Provides the connection pool for asynchronous SQLx connections.

[postgres](https://docs.rs/sqlx/latest/sqlx/postgres/index.html "mod sqlx::postgres")`postgres`
    **PostgreSQL** database driver.

[prelude](https://docs.rs/sqlx/latest/sqlx/prelude/index.html "mod sqlx::prelude")
    Convenience re-export of common traits.

[query](https://docs.rs/sqlx/latest/sqlx/query/index.html "mod sqlx::query")
    Types and traits for the `query` family of functions and macros.

[query_builder](https://docs.rs/sqlx/latest/sqlx/query_builder/index.html "mod sqlx::query_builder")
    Runtime query-builder API.

[sqlite](https://docs.rs/sqlx/latest/sqlx/sqlite/index.html "mod sqlx::sqlite")`_sqlite`
    **SQLite** database driver.

[types](https://docs.rs/sqlx/latest/sqlx/types/index.html "mod sqlx::types")
    Conversions between Rust and SQL types.
## Macros[§](https://docs.rs/sqlx/latest/sqlx/#macros)

[migrate](https://docs.rs/sqlx/latest/sqlx/macro.migrate.html "macro sqlx::migrate")
    Embeds migrations into the binary by expanding to a static instance of [Migrator](https://docs.rs/sqlx/latest/sqlx/migrate/struct.Migrator.html "struct sqlx::migrate::Migrator").

[query](https://docs.rs/sqlx/latest/sqlx/macro.query.html "macro sqlx::query")`macros`
    Statically checked SQL query with `println!()` style syntax.

[query_as](https://docs.rs/sqlx/latest/sqlx/macro.query_as.html "macro sqlx::query_as")`macros`
    A variant of [`query!`](https://docs.rs/sqlx/latest/sqlx/macro.query.html "macro sqlx::query") which takes a path to an explicitly defined struct as the output type.

[query_as_unchecked](https://docs.rs/sqlx/latest/sqlx/macro.query_as_unchecked.html "macro sqlx::query_as_unchecked")`macros`
    A variant of [`query_as!`](https://docs.rs/sqlx/latest/sqlx/macro.query_as.html "macro sqlx::query_as") which does not check the input or output types. This still does parse the query to ensure it’s syntactically and semantically valid for the current database.

[query_file](https://docs.rs/sqlx/latest/sqlx/macro.query_file.html "macro sqlx::query_file")`macros`
    A variant of [`query!`](https://docs.rs/sqlx/latest/sqlx/macro.query.html "macro sqlx::query") where the SQL query is stored in a separate file.

[query_file_as](https://docs.rs/sqlx/latest/sqlx/macro.query_file_as.html "macro sqlx::query_file_as")`macros`
    Combines the syntaxes of [`query_as!`](https://docs.rs/sqlx/latest/sqlx/macro.query_as.html "macro sqlx::query_as") and [`query_file!`](https://docs.rs/sqlx/latest/sqlx/macro.query_file.html "macro sqlx::query_file").

[query_file_as_unchecked](https://docs.rs/sqlx/latest/sqlx/macro.query_file_as_unchecked.html "macro sqlx::query_file_as_unchecked")`macros`
    A variant of [`query_file_as!`](https://docs.rs/sqlx/latest/sqlx/macro.query_file_as.html "macro sqlx::query_file_as") which does not check the input or output types. This still does parse the query to ensure it’s syntactically and semantically valid for the current database.

[query_file_scalar](https://docs.rs/sqlx/latest/sqlx/macro.query_file_scalar.html "macro sqlx::query_file_scalar")`macros`
    A variant of [`query_scalar!`](https://docs.rs/sqlx/latest/sqlx/macro.query_scalar.html "macro sqlx::query_scalar") which takes a file path like [`query_file!`](https://docs.rs/sqlx/latest/sqlx/macro.query_file.html "macro sqlx::query_file").

[query_file_scalar_unchecked](https://docs.rs/sqlx/latest/sqlx/macro.query_file_scalar_unchecked.html "macro sqlx::query_file_scalar_unchecked")`macros`
    A variant of [`query_file_scalar!`](https://docs.rs/sqlx/latest/sqlx/macro.query_file_scalar.html "macro sqlx::query_file_scalar") which does not typecheck bind parameters and leaves the output type to inference. The query itself is still checked that it is syntactically and semantically valid for the database, that it only produces one column and that the number of bind parameters is correct.

[query_file_unchecked](https://docs.rs/sqlx/latest/sqlx/macro.query_file_unchecked.html "macro sqlx::query_file_unchecked")`macros`
    A variant of [`query_file!`](https://docs.rs/sqlx/latest/sqlx/macro.query_file.html "macro sqlx::query_file") which does not check the input or output types. This still does parse the query to ensure it’s syntactically and semantically valid for the current database.

[query_scalar](https://docs.rs/sqlx/latest/sqlx/macro.query_scalar.html "macro sqlx::query_scalar")`macros`
    A variant of [`query!`](https://docs.rs/sqlx/latest/sqlx/macro.query.html "macro sqlx::query") which expects a single column from the query and evaluates to an instance of [QueryScalar](https://docs.rs/sqlx/latest/sqlx/query/struct.QueryScalar.html "struct sqlx::query::QueryScalar").

[query_scalar_unchecked](https://docs.rs/sqlx/latest/sqlx/macro.query_scalar_unchecked.html "macro sqlx::query_scalar_unchecked")`macros`
    A variant of [`query_scalar!`](https://docs.rs/sqlx/latest/sqlx/macro.query_scalar.html "macro sqlx::query_scalar") which does not typecheck bind parameters and leaves the output type to inference. The query itself is still checked that it is syntactically and semantically valid for the database, that it only produces one column and that the number of bind parameters is correct.

[query_unchecked](https://docs.rs/sqlx/latest/sqlx/macro.query_unchecked.html "macro sqlx::query_unchecked")`macros`
    A variant of [`query!`](https://docs.rs/sqlx/latest/sqlx/macro.query.html "macro sqlx::query") which does not check the input or output types. This still does parse the query to ensure it’s syntactically and semantically valid for the current database.
## Structs[§](https://docs.rs/sqlx/latest/sqlx/#structs)

[Any](https://docs.rs/sqlx/latest/sqlx/struct.Any.html "struct sqlx::Any")`any`
    Opaque database driver. Capable of being used in place of any SQLx database driver. The actual driver used will be selected at runtime, from the connection url.

[AnyConnection](https://docs.rs/sqlx/latest/sqlx/struct.AnyConnection.html "struct sqlx::AnyConnection")
    **SEE DOCUMENTATION BEFORE USE**. Runtime-generic database connection.

[MySql](https://docs.rs/sqlx/latest/sqlx/struct.MySql.html "struct sqlx::MySql")`mysql`
    MySQL database driver.

[MySqlConnection](https://docs.rs/sqlx/latest/sqlx/struct.MySqlConnection.html "struct sqlx::MySqlConnection")`mysql`
    A connection to a MySQL database.

[PgConnection](https://docs.rs/sqlx/latest/sqlx/struct.PgConnection.html "struct sqlx::PgConnection")`postgres`
    A connection to a PostgreSQL database.

[Pool](https://docs.rs/sqlx/latest/sqlx/struct.Pool.html "struct sqlx::Pool")
    An asynchronous pool of SQLx database connections.

[Postgres](https://docs.rs/sqlx/latest/sqlx/struct.Postgres.html "struct sqlx::Postgres")`postgres`
    PostgreSQL database driver.

[QueryBuilder](https://docs.rs/sqlx/latest/sqlx/struct.QueryBuilder.html "struct sqlx::QueryBuilder")
    A builder type for constructing queries at runtime.

[RawSql](https://docs.rs/sqlx/latest/sqlx/struct.RawSql.html "struct sqlx::RawSql")
    One or more raw SQL statements, separated by semicolons (`;`).

[Sqlite](https://docs.rs/sqlx/latest/sqlx/struct.Sqlite.html "struct sqlx::Sqlite")`_sqlite`
    Sqlite database driver.

[SqliteConnection](https://docs.rs/sqlx/latest/sqlx/struct.SqliteConnection.html "struct sqlx::SqliteConnection")`_sqlite`
    A connection to an open [Sqlite](https://docs.rs/sqlx/latest/sqlx/struct.Sqlite.html "struct sqlx::Sqlite") database.

[Transaction](https://docs.rs/sqlx/latest/sqlx/struct.Transaction.html "struct sqlx::Transaction")
    An in-progress database transaction or savepoint.
## Enums[§](https://docs.rs/sqlx/latest/sqlx/#enums)

[Either](https://docs.rs/sqlx/latest/sqlx/enum.Either.html "enum sqlx::Either")
    The enum `Either` with variants `Left` and `Right` is a general purpose sum type with two cases.

[Error](https://docs.rs/sqlx/latest/sqlx/enum.Error.html "enum sqlx::Error")
    Represents all the ways a method can fail within SQLx.
## Traits[§](https://docs.rs/sqlx/latest/sqlx/#traits)

# Crate sqlxCopy item path
Settings⟨1⟩
Help⟨2⟩
SummarySource⟨3⟩
Expand description
The async SQL toolkit for Rust, built with ❤️ by the LaunchBadge team⟨4⟩.
See our README⟨5⟩ to get started or browse our example projects⟨6⟩. Have a question? Check our FAQ⟨7⟩ or open a discussion⟨8⟩.
#### §⟨9⟩Runtime Support
SQLx supports both the Tokio⟨10⟩ and async-std⟨11⟩ runtimes.
You choose which runtime SQLx uses by default by enabling one of the following features:
  * `runtime-async-std`
  * `runtime-tokio`


The `runtime-actix` feature also exists but is an alias of `runtime-tokio`.
If more than one runtime feature is enabled, the Tokio runtime is used if a Tokio context exists on the current thread, i.e. `tokio::runtime::Handle::try_current()`⟨12⟩ returns `Ok`; `async-std` is used otherwise.
Note that while SQLx no longer produces a compile error if zero or multiple runtime features are enabled, which is useful for libraries building on top of it, **the use of nearly any async function in the API will panic without at least one runtime feature enabled**.
The chief exception is the SQLite driver, which is runtime-agnostic, including its integration with the query macros. However, `SqlitePool`⟨13⟩ _does_ require runtime support for timeouts and spawning internal management tasks.
#### §⟨14⟩TLS Support
For securely communicating with SQL servers over an untrusted network connection such as the internet, you can enable Transport Layer Security (TLS) by enabling one of the following features:
  * `tls-native-tls`: Enables the `native-tls`⟨15⟩ backend which uses the OS-native TLS capabilities: 
    * SecureTransport on macOS.
    * SChannel on Windows.
    * OpenSSL on all other platforms.
  * `tls-rustls`: Enables the rustls⟨16⟩ backend, a cross-platform TLS library. 
    * Only supports TLS revisions 1.2 and 1.3.
    * If you get `HandshakeFailure` errors when using this feature, it likely means your database server does not support these newer revisions. This might be resolved by enabling or switching to the `tls-native-tls` feature.
    * rustls supports several providers of cryptographic primitives. The default (enabled when you use the `tls-rustls` feature or `tls-rustls-ring`) is the `ring` provider, which has fewer build-time dependencies but also has fewer features. Alternatively, you can use `tls-rustls-aws-lc-rs` to use the `aws-lc-rs` provider, which enables additional cipher suite support at the cost of more onerous build requirements (depending on platform support).


If more than one TLS feature is enabled, the `tls-native-tls` feature takes precedent so that it is only necessary to enable it to see if it resolves the `HandshakeFailure` error without disabling `tls-rustls`.
Consult the user manual for your database to find the TLS versions it supports.
If your connection configuration requires a TLS upgrade but TLS support was not enabled, the connection attempt will return an error.
The legacy runtime+TLS combination feature flags are still supported, but for forward-compatibility, use of the separate runtime and TLS feature flags is recommended.

## Macros§⟨34⟩

    Embeds migrations into the binary by expanding to a static instance of Migrator⟨36⟩.

query⟨37⟩`macros`
    Statically checked SQL query with `println!()` style syntax.

query_as⟨38⟩`macros`
    A variant of `query!`⟨37⟩ which takes a path to an explicitly defined struct as the output type.

query_as_unchecked⟨39⟩`macros`
    A variant of `query_as!`⟨38⟩ which does not check the input or output types. This still does parse the query to ensure it’s syntactically and semantically valid for the current database.

query_file⟨40⟩`macros`
    A variant of `query!`⟨37⟩ where the SQL query is stored in a separate file.

query_file_as⟨41⟩`macros`
    Combines the syntaxes of `query_as!`⟨38⟩ and `query_file!`⟨40⟩.

query_file_as_unchecked⟨42⟩`macros`
    A variant of `query_file_as!`⟨41⟩ which does not check the input or output types. This still does parse the query to ensure it’s syntactically and semantically valid for the current database.

query_file_scalar⟨43⟩`macros`
    A variant of `query_scalar!`⟨44⟩ which takes a file path like `query_file!`⟨40⟩.

query_file_scalar_unchecked⟨45⟩`macros`
    A variant of `query_file_scalar!`⟨43⟩ which does not typecheck bind parameters and leaves the output type to inference. The query itself is still checked that it is syntactically and semantically valid for the database, that it only produces one column and that the number of bind parameters is correct.

query_file_unchecked⟨46⟩`macros`
    A variant of `query_file!`⟨40⟩ which does not check the input or output types. This still does parse the query to ensure it’s syntactically and semantically valid for the current database.

query_scalar⟨44⟩`macros`
    A variant of `query!`⟨37⟩ which expects a single column from the query and evaluates to an instance of QueryScalar⟨47⟩.

query_scalar_unchecked⟨48⟩`macros`
    A variant of `query_scalar!`⟨44⟩ which does not typecheck bind parameters and leaves the output type to inference. The query itself is still checked that it is syntactically and semantically valid for the database, that it only produces one column and that the number of bind parameters is correct.

query_unchecked⟨49⟩`macros`
    A variant of `query!`⟨37⟩ which does not check the input or output types. This still does parse the query to ensure it’s syntactically and semantically valid for the current database.

enriched_crate.readme_summary: The `sqlx` crate is an asynchronous SQL toolkit for Rust, supporting runtime-agnostic database interactions with drivers for PostgreSQL, MySQL, and SQLite. It offers compile-time checked queries, connection pooling, migrations, and seamless Rust-to-SQL type conversions. Key features include runtime support for `tokio` and `async-std`, TLS integration, and a rich set of macros for building and validating SQL queries.
enriched_crate.factual_counterfactual:
### Pair 1: Runtime Support  
✅ Factual: SQLx supports both the Tokio and async-std runtimes for asynchronous operations, and defaults to Tokio if both runtime features are enabled.  
❌ Counterfactual: SQLx exclusively supports the Tokio runtime and cannot be used with async-std or other runtimes.  

---

### Pair 2: TLS Support  
✅ Factual: SQLx provides TLS support through the `tls-native-tls` and `tls-rustls` features, allowing secure communication with SQL servers over untrusted networks.  
❌ Counterfactual: SQLx does not support TLS for secure communication, requiring users to implement their own encryption mechanisms.  

---

### Pair 3: SQLite Runtime-Agnostic Behavior  
✅ Factual: SQLx's SQLite driver is runtime-agnostic, meaning it does not depend on a specific async runtime for basic operations, though `SqlitePool` requires runtime support for tasks like timeouts.  
❌ Counterfactual: SQLx's SQLite driver mandates the use of the Tokio runtime and cannot function without it.
